metadata.title: Changes in anatomical and functional connectivity of Parkinsons disease patients according to cognitive status
metadata.abstract: Purpose: This study assesses the patterns of structural and functional connectivity damage in patients with Parkinsons disease dementia (PDD) compared with cognitively unimpaired Parkinsons disease patients (PD-Cu) and healthy controls (HC). Materials and methods: Resting state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI) and diffusion tensor magnetic resonance imaging (DTI) scans were obtained from 30 PD and 21 sex-and age-matched HC. The between-group difference in posterior cingulate (PCC) functional connectivity (FC) was performed to assess FC dysfunction. Atlas-based spatial statistics of DTI was applied to compare White matter (WM) fibers impairment between groups. Results: (1) Functional connectivity: (1) PD-Cu compared with HC showed a decreased PCC functional connectivity of the right medial temporal lobe (MTL). In addition, PCC-right MTL connectivity strength of PD was significantly correlated with Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score. (2) PDD group shows a decreased FC of PCC-right parahippocampa compared with PD-Cu group; while show a widespread decreased PCC FC compared with HC group. (2) Anatomical connectivity: (1) Relative to PD-Cu, significant lower FA values were found in the left hippocampus in PDD. (2) PDD showed higher MD values in a widespread WM regions compared with PD-Cu and HC. (3) Positive correlation was observed between MoCA score and FA value of left inferior longitudinal and hippocampus, and bilateral superior longitudinal fasciculus in PD. Conclusions: Cognitive decline in PD is associated with FC damage of PCC-right MTL and microstructural damage of left hippocampus. Nevertheless, combining fMRI and DTI method may provide markers able to contribute to the prediction of PDD.

Introduction.text:
Parkinsons disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder diagnosed on the basis of characteristic motor disturbance (resting tremor, rigidity, postural instability and bradykinesia), asymmetrical symptom onset, and good response to levodopa 1. However, cognitive impairment is a well-defined non-motor manifestation of PD, which is characterized by visuospatial and executive dysfunctions, as well as deficits of attention and shortterm recall. Parkinson disease dementia (PDD) develops in up to 80 of patients with PD and has a profound socioeconomic impact 2. Early-stage identification of risk factors for PDD development is valuable from a prognostic perspective as well as for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies. Therefore, there is an intensive search for biomarkers that may predict the progression from cognitively unimpaired PD patients (PD-Cu) to PDD.
The loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is considered the hallmark neuropathological finding of Parkinsons disease 3. Yet pathological and psychopharmacological studies have suggested that cognitive decline in PD can be secondary to cortical Lewy bodies (LBs) accumulation, Alzheimers pathology, dysfunction of dopaminergic and nondopaminergic neurotransmitter systems, and vascular lesions 4.
Recently, resting-state functional MRI (rs-fMRI) has emerged as a potential means of elucidating functional brain architecture 5. Resting-state functional connectivity is attractive for the characterization of complex interactions between brain regions, which describes temporal correlations blood of oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) time series. Rs-fMRI has been adopted as a biomarker in natural history and interventional studies of Alzheimers disease 6 and amnestic mild cognitive impairment 7, but its utility as a biomarker for PD and PDD is unclear. Resting-state networks (RSNs) are characterized by organized basal activity during rest and by low-frequency signal fluctuations that can be studied by fMRI. The RSNs have been less studied using fMRI in PD, but studies have shown rather variable results 8. In PDD, preliminary studies have shown a different pattern, with decreased FC reminiscent of the changes in Alzheimers disease 9.
Because diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) can reveal abnormalities in white matter fiber structure and provide models of anatomical connectivity (AC), it is rapidly becoming a standard for white matter disorders 10. DTI has been used to demonstrate the role of white matter in PD patients cognitive function. Some studies 111213 assess connectivity alterations in PD, showed that WM damage is associated with the degree of global cognitive impairment, and shown PDD have significant white matter deterioration in a number of brain regions such as the cingulum 11,12, corpus callosum 11, frontal, temporal, and occipital lobes 12,13.
In summary, DTI and rs-fMRI studies have revealed abnormalities in several areas of the brain in PD, these methods have expanded our understanding of the disease beyond dopaminergic deficits. However, the neuroanatomical basis and topography of the neurobiological processes that account for these cognitive impairments have not been well characterized due to limitations in prior single-mode neuroimaging analyses. In contrast to the previous studies investigating FC or AC changes in PD, here we combined resting state functional MRI and DTI techniques in the same individuals to explore PD patients cognitive impairment.

Participants.text: We studied 30 PD patients and 21 healthy sex-and age-matched volunteers. All participants were right-handed. All patients had a diagnosis of idiopathic PD based on medical history, physical and neurological examinations, response to levodopa or dopaminergic drugs, and laboratory tests and MRI scans to exclude other diseases. Only mild to moderate stage patients were enrolled to ensure compliance with the long scan time. This study was approved by the Medical Research Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital of China Medical University. Written informed consent was obtained from All participants.

Diagnostic criteria and assessment.text: The severity of motor symptoms was assessed by means of the motor section of the Unified Parkinsons Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS-III) 14, and by Hoehn and Yahr (HY) classification of disease stage. On the basis of comprehensive neuropsychological testing, patients with Parkinsons disease were classified as cognitively normal (n  19) or with dementia (n  11). Dementia classification was based on the Movement Disorders Society Task Force criteria 15. Global cognitive status was measured with Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) 16 and the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) 17. The clinical and demographic data of the participants are shown in Table 1.

Magnetic resonance imaging acquisition.text: MRI scans were performed on a 3.0-Tesla General Electric Signa System after a minimum period of 12 h since the patients last dose of anti-Parkinson medication. A standard head coil was used with foam padding to reduce head motion and scanner noise. Three-dimensional T1-weighted images were acquired in a sagittal orientation employing a 3D-SPGR sequence TR  7.1 ms, TE  3.2 ms, flip angle  15  , field of view (FOV)  24 cm  24 cm, matrix  256  256; 172 slices were collected with 1.0 mm thickness without gap. The RS-fMRI scanning was performed in darkness, and the participants were explicitly instructed to keep their Eyes closed, relax, and move as little as possible. Functional images were collected using a gradient echo planar imaging (EPI) sequence sensitive to BOLD contrast TR  3000 ms, TE  60 ms, flip angle  90  , FOV  24 cm  24 cm, matrix  64  64. Sixty axial slices were collected with 3 mm thickness without gap; in all, 9600 images were acquired during fMRI scanning.

Data preprocessing.text: Data were preprocessed and analyzed by using the Pipeline for Analyzing Brain Diffusion Images toolkit (PANDA; http: www.nitrc.orgprojectspanda), which synthesizes procedures in FSL (http:fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.ukfsl), diffusion toolkit (http:www. nmr.mgh.harvard.edurpwangdtk), and MRIcron (http:www. mccauslandcenter.sc.edumricromricron). For each subject, eddy current correction was used to correct for distortions and head motion on the DTI sequences by aligning the diffusion weighted images to the b  0 image. After that, the alignde multiple DWI was averaged by calling the fslmaths command of FSL. Then, we calculate the diffusion tensor metrics.

Definition of ROIs.text: The bilateral PCC ROI was defined by WFU PickAtlas (http: www.ansir.wfubmc.edu) and were resliced into Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space. For each ROI, the BOLD time series of the voxels within the ROI were averaged to generate the reference time series for this ROI.

Functional connectivity and statistical.text:
A voxel-wise FC analysis of the ROI was used. Correlation analysis was carried out between the seed reference and the entire brain in a voxel-wise manner using REST. Correlation coefficients were transformed to z-values using the Fisher r-to-z transformation to improve normality.
Functional connectivity (FC) comparison in groups was compared with single factor variance analysis (One way ANOVA), and the pairwise comparison was performed with Bonferroni method. Finally, in order to investigate the relationship between the FC strength and cognitive function, correlation analyses were performed between the z-values maps and the MOCA scores in PD patients. The contrast maps threshold was set at p  0.01 for each voxel, with a cluster size of at least 1080mm3, which was equal to the corrected threshold of p  0.05, as determined by AlphaSim (http:afni.nimh.nih.govpubdistdocmanualAlphaSim.pdf).

Producing diffusion metrics that are rea.text: To allow for comparison across subjects, we non-linear registered individual images of native space to the template in the MNI space. The resultant warping transformations were then used to resample the images of the diffusion metrics (FA and MD) into the MNI space with 1 mm  1 mm  1 mm spatial resolution. We use Johns Hopkins Universitys Mori white matter atlas (http:cmrm. med.jhmi.edu) to do the parcellation of the entire WM into multiple ROIs. PANDA calculates the regional diffusion metrics by averaging the values within each region of the WM atlases. These resultant ROI-based data were saved as text files. Only major commissural fibers and association fibers are reported (Table 2).

Statistical analysis.text: We conducted one-way ANOVA to assess between-group differences in diffusion metrics. Following ANOVA, we conducted pairwise comparison with Bonferroni method. Correlations between diffusion metrics and MoCA were measured with Pearson correlation within the PD group. All analyses were performed using Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS 20.0) with an alpha level set at 0.05 (2-tailed).

Statistical analysis of clinical and beh.text: In the comparisons of some demographic information and clinical characteristics (age, education, MMSE, MoCA), one-way ANOVA with LSD test post hoc comparisons were used. On the other hand, disease duration, HY, and UPDRS III were compared between PDD and PD-Cu with two sample t-test; Fisher exact test was used to compare sex distributions among the groups. All data were statistically analyzed using SPSS 20.0. Two-sided values of p  0.05 were considered statistically significant (Table 1).

Result.text: Demographic and neuropsychiatric date are included in Table 1. There were no age F  0.878, P  0.422, sex Fisher exact test, P  1.00, education F  1.888, P  0.162, or disease duration differences t  0.5, P  0.621 observed among the groups. Although PDD tend to have higher HY and UPDRS-III scores than PD-Cu, there were no significant group differences or trends toward significance observed t  1.918, P  0.065; t  1.731, P  0.094. Compared to PD-Cu and HC, PDD showed a lower MMSE score and MOCA score. Compared to HC, PD-Cu showed a lower MOCA score.

PD-Cu versus HC.text: No DTI measurement differences were found between PD-Cu and HC.

PDD versus PD-Cu.text: Compared with PD-Cu, significant lower FA values were found in the left hippocampus in PDD (p  0.05), while PDD showed higher MD values in the right superior fronto-occipital fasciculus, right cingulate gyrus, left inferior longitudinal fasciculus, left Superior longitudinal fasciculus, bilateral uncinate fasciculus in PDD (p  0.05).

PDD versus HC.text: Compared with healthy controls, significant higher MD values were found in the splenium and body of corpus callosum, right superior fronto-occipital fasciculus, left Superior longitudinal fasciculus, bilateral uncinate fasciculus in PDD (p  0.05). No regions of decreased FA were found in PDD compared with PD-Cu.

Correlations analysis.text: By using the Pearson correlation, we find a significant positive correlation between the PCC functional connectivity strength of right middle temporal gyrus, right fusiform gyrus and MoCA score (Fig. 3).

Correlations.text: By using the Pearson correlation, we found Positive correlation between MoCA scores and FA values of left hippocampus (r  0.54, P  .002), and bilateral superior longitudinal fasciculus (L:r  0.373, P  .042, R:r  0.398, P  .029). Negative correlation was observed between MoCA scores and MD values of right uncinate fasciculus (r  -0.390, P  .033), and left inferior longitudinal fasciculus (r  -0.406, P  .026), and left superior longitudinal fasciculus (r  -0.362, P  .049).

Discussion.text:
We evaluate specific differences in connectivity patterns across 3 groups of subjects: HC, PD-Cu and PDD; and the relationship of altered connectivity and cognitive performance in PD. Functional Magnetic Resonance imaging (fMRI) can localize the human cortical area that correlate with cognitive function and characterize the magnetic resonance signal change, but it cannot provide the information of white matter. Diffusion Tensor imaging (DTI) can demonstrate the anatomical connectivity of the human brain in vivo at present. Yet it can provide little information about the cortex. So, fMRI and DTI are complementary, and fMRI in combination with DTI is a promising tool in the neuroscience research. In recent years, some studies 18,19 combining functional MRI and diffusion imaging in the same individuals. Pathologically, PDD is most often associated with the presence of cortical Lewy bodies (LB). A study of PD cases assessing cognitive impairment from retrospective chart reviews showed that severity of cognitive impairment correlated with cortical LBs, especially in cingulate gyrus, even when Alzheimer disease was not present 20. The default mode network (DMN) is one of the most studied RSNs, includes the medial prefrontal cortex, posterior cingulate cortex, precuneus, and lateral parietal and temporal cortices 21, and is believed to be involved in higher cognitive functions. Previous studies showed the impaired deactivation of the DMN in parkinson disease 8. Most importantly, PCC has been considered as structural and functional core in this network 22. Convergent evidence from histopathologic 20, DTI 11,12 and fMRI consistently suggests that PCC is a key structure in the pathophysiology of PDD. The major finding was an early decreased functional connectivity of PCC-right MTL, in PD-Cu. In deed, we observed a positive association between MoCA score and PCC-right MTL FC strength. This result was high agree with a previous studies 23. PDD showed a decreased PCC-right parahippocampa gyrus FC, and a higher MD values in right cingulate gyrus. Our results were supported by a previous pathology study. The authors examined cognitive impairment in PD, LBs were found most in the cingulate, middle temporal and angular. On the other hand, Studies found PCC-right PCC has direct connections to the MTL, which has direct connections to the hippocampus via both the polysynaptic and direct intrahippocampal pathway 24. In addition, one of the primary long association fibers of PCC is the cingulum bundle, through which PCC has connections that terminate in parahippocampal gyrus WM 25.Taken together, results supporting the idea that early deficits in PCC-right middle temporal gyrus connectivity lead to an increased vulnerability to early cognitive impairment appearing in progression from PD-Cu to PDD.
On the other hand, we found FA values of left hippocampus significantly reduced in PDD, and positive correlated with MoCA score. Our result agree well with the study of Camicioli et al. 26, they found the hippocampal volume showed a pattern progressive hippocampal volume loss in PD (HC  PD  PDD); recognition memory and Mini-Mental State Examination scores correlated with left hippocampal volume among PD and PDD. Furthermore, we found an enhanced functional connection of PCC-left lingual. The lingual gyrus is a brain structure that is linked to processing vision, especially related to letters. It is thought to also play a role in analysis of logical conditions and encoding visual memories 27. Notably, A previous studie suggested a potential link between the lingual gyrus and hippocampal regions in the brain 28. We assume that the lingual gyrus play a compensatory role in PD patients cognitive impairment.
Therefore, we found significantly increased FC of PCC-bilateral IPC in PD-Cu, however this increased FC have not be found in PDD. One the other hand, bilateral superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF) damage have been found in PDD. Studies have shown that examination of structural connections between the PCC and the bilateral IPC is complicated by the crossing fiber tracts of the anterior to posterior SLF and the superior to inferior corona radiata tracts that separate them 29. This finding suggests that increased FC of PCC-IPC play a compensatory role in PD-Cu, while extensive global white matter degeneration in PDD group make this lose. In addition, our findings were generally consistent with previous studies 13, suggest that individuals with PDD have a widespread damage of white matter when compared to PD-Cu and HC, whereas PD-Cu did not show WM abnormalities.
Our study is not without limitations. First, the patient sample size is relatively small and our results have to be considered preliminary; Second, the potentially confounding effects of chronic dopaminergic medications are not considered in our work. Thirdly, head motion would in turn imply deteriorate image quality. Although our current study excluded the motion artifacts of basic and simple global head movement, the details of the head motions are not assessed in the current investigation. To be prudent, Further studies might determine whether more detailed motion derived parameters. Finally, recent studies 30 have indicated that mild cognitive impairment in PD(PD-MCI) have a higher risk to develop dementia. Future studies will need to recruit larger samples including patients with PD-MCI to confirm our findings.

Conclusions.text: In conclusion, we found that cognitive decline in PD is associated with abnormalities of structural and functional connections, especially associated with functional connectivity damage of PCCthe right MTL and microstructural damage of left hippocampus. The relationship between connectivity abnormalities and clinical markers obtained using both techniques provided the evidence that the damage of structural connectivity might be the physical foundation in the impairment of functional connectivity. Nevertheless, combining using Rs-fMRI and DTI method might provides a crucial multi-modal validation and reveals the change of the neuron and white matter, which can be valuable for the early diagnosis of PDD.
